stream_context.summary: Kaze blocks-out and refines the cardboard-craft themed Course 14: draws multiple traversal paths, relocates the spawn point, prototypes props (toilet-paper-roll mushrooms, crayons, fences, cardboard mountains) and repeatedly checks performance on real N64 hardware. A sizeable part of the stream is spent diagnosing over-draw, fine-tuning RSP optimisations, and hunting assets (e.g. a toilet-paper texture).

development_findings.summary: Course 14 is intended to mimic the non-linear structure of Peach’s Fury; Kaze draws at least five interconnected paths plus a paper-airplane warp and wants each route to serve a distinct collectible purpose.
development_findings.quote: This is very similar to the layout in Peach's Fury and that one was really not linear.

development_findings.summary: The spawn point was moved to a central island to balance navigation and give players multiple opening choices.
development_findings.quote: I think we want the spawn point to be here. This is more balanced and in the middle of the level.

development_findings.summary: New craft-style props confirmed or prototyped: toilet-paper-roll mushrooms (gift-wrap top + staple), crayons/ruler platforms, cardboard fences, glue zones that shorten jumps, tilt-bridges held by toothpicks, a toilet-paper-roll slide, and a paper-airplane that ferries Mario to the big pipe.

Level currently uses ~3-4 K triangles but suffers from heavy over-draw; RDP time 36.8 ms versus RSP 18–22 ms (≈50 FPS ceiling). Plan is to cut hidden geometry and disable Z-buffer on skybox to reclaim budget.
development_findings.quote: You see 18 milliseconds RSP… the RDP is at 36.8. That means it's all the overdraw.

development_findings.summary: Kaze saved ~30 RSP instructions by caching GMAT stack indices and inlining maths; he may gain ~20 more by replacing gMatStackIndex with a pointer-add version.
development_findings.quote: I found 30 instruction improvement in Graph Render again … I'm going to try to replace GMAT stack index with GMAT stack add.

development_findings.summary: Real-hardware testing is now done exclusively with the USB-based SummerCart, which flashes builds in seconds and is judged more reliable and cheaper than the EverDrive X7.
development_findings.quote: The EverDrive X7 is dog-shit … The SummerCart just works.

development_findings.summary: A limited public demo (only Course 1) is planned for release ‘soon’ to gather feedback.
Kaze considers creating beginner-friendly YouTube explainer videos (e.g., how BLJ works) as low-effort content to boost channel reach.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is self-employed; still takes commissions but at ‘hefty’ rates.
Streamer finances: SimpleFlips has sent ≈$3,500 but lack of address prevents formal invoicing and final payment.
context_findings.quote: He sent me like around $3,500 at this point, but I can't write an invoice to him because he didn't give me his address.

context_findings.summary: Personal notes: proud of new automatic lawn-mower (‘I have become a boomer’); enjoys chocolate rewards; had a stressful nightmare about social-media backlash.
Emotional tone oscillates between excitement over optimisations and mild frustration when asset hunting or debating difficulty.

zeina.summary: Present in chat; jokingly assigned the role of ‘chat mom’, but no production tasks discussed.

key_stories.title: Toilet-Paper-Roll Mushroom
key_stories.summary: Kaze needs a craft-style platform to liven up flat areas, settles on a mushroom built from a toilet-paper roll, gift-wrap cap, and a 3D staple.
key_stories.challenge: Find a convincing, low-poly prop and suitable texture within N64 limits.
key_stories.process: Searched online, balked at paid assets, accepted a Discord user’s texture, modelled the roll and staple, tweaked a shader for subtle gift-wrap shine.
key_stories.outcome: Prop approved for Course 14; doubles as example of ‘materials must look realistic to be convincing’.
key_stories.key_quote: This mushroom here works … we all know wrap paper has a little bit of a shine to it, so if it doesn't have the shine, people might not identify it.

key_stories.title: Rendering Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Course 14 initially ran slowly on real hardware; Kaze clawed back RSP time through code-level hacks.
key_stories.challenge: Graph render functions were executing redundant instructions, limiting frame-rate.
key_stories.process: Cached GMAT stack index, inlined VAC3F cross, used restrict qualifiers; identified further gains via pointer arithmetic.
key_stories.outcome: ~30 saved instructions (with ~20 more possible) and a path toward smoother 50 FPS cap.
key_stories.key_quote: I saved 30 instructions on graph render today which is very exciting.

key_stories.title: Choosing the SummerCart
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed fast iteration on real N64 hardware.
key_stories.challenge: EverDrive X7’s 40-second SD flashes and reliability issues slowed testing.
key_stories.process: Compared devices live; demonstrated SummerCart’s USB upload completing in seconds.
key_stories.outcome: SummerCart adopted as default hardware test platform for the project.
key_stories.key_quote: Just because something costs more doesn't mean it's better; the SummerCart is cheaper and works.
